data.title: Has anyone experienced native 7.1 when streaming Dolby Digital Plus?
data.meta_description:
This is a question for all those with systems capable of playing back a native 7.1 bitstream signal i.e. those folk that have back surround channels.

The...

#1

This is a question for all those with systems capable of playing back a native 7.1 bitstream signal i.e. those folk that have back surround channels.

The Dolby Digital Plus codec has supported 7.1 discrete audio channels since its inception >15 years ago yet I've never once noticed any of my AVRs' decoders flag a Netflix or Amazon streamed audio bitstream signal as being "DD+ 7.1". Instead I've only ever seen it engage the default Dolby surround back channel upmixer which, in the case of my pre-Atmos AVRs, is "DD+ PLIIx Cinema". I have seen DD+ 7.1 on Blu-ray before though (when I had the player's settings wrong) so I know the AVR can do it.

I would have thought that the many movies that were mastered in 7.1 would be streamed in this format but, given the above, suspect these are all being downmixed into DD+5.1 to reduce bandwidth usage.

Has anyone ever experienced native DD+ 7.1 via a streaming service?

dante01

#2

I'd hazzard that it is due to the additional bandwidth needed to convey a 7.1 stream compared to what is required for a 5.1 audio stream? Atmos doesn't actually have additional channels and is merely metadata packaged with the 5.1 DD+ audio so wouldn't put as much strain on the bandwidth as including 2 discrete back channels would.

It is basically the same reason streaming services haven't adopted HD formats and drawn the line at DD+. Bandwidth.

No, I've never received anythiong more than 5.1 DD+ or Atmos via any of the mainstream streaming srvices.

I don't currently subscribe to the Apple TV+ service, but I've see it posted elsewhere that 'Foundation' is inclusive of a 7.1 DD+ soundtrack? There are also other reports that some films accessed via Apple are also encoded with 7.1 audio?

#3

I'd hazzard that it is due to the additional bandwidth needed to convey a 7.1 stream compared to what is required for a 5.1 audio stream?

OK, that's what I said I think is going on.

Atmos doesn;t actually have additional channels and is merely metadata packaged with the 5.1 DD+ audio so wouldn't put as much strain on the bandwidth as including 2 discrete back channels would.

This is interesting though. Someone with an Atmos capable AVR who's running a traditional non-Atmos 7.1 speaker layout should get discrete 7.1 surround sound with an Atmos encoded DD+ bitstream from say Netflix. Of course this assumes the source streaming device supports Atmos bitstreams, not all do. In fact almost all TVs made before 2019 do not.

#5

OK, that's what I said I think is going on.

This is interesting though. Someone with an Atmos capable AVR who's running a traditional non-Atmos 7.1 speaker layout should get discrete 7.1 surround sound with an Atmos bitstream from say Netflix. Of course this assumes the source streaming device supports Atmos bitstreams, not all do. In fact almost all TVs made before 2019 do not.

That depends on whether or not the audio is inclusive of Atmos or not. An Atmos setup will always priotioties the Atmos metadata which which then negate the channel based soundtrack. You'd basically have to disengage or turn off the height speakers in the setup to force the receiver to use the discrete channel based format the metadata was packaged with. Yes, the Atmos soundtrack uses the channel based audio, but Atmos AV receivers don't give you an option to flick between Atmos and the channel based audio, not without ammending the speaker configurations and disabling the height and or ceiling speakers.

It should also be noted that even without heoght speakers, an AV receiver will still give you Atmos if you've back surrounds present in a setup. This makes it practically impossible to actually portrat a discrete 7.1 soundtrack even if you turn the height speakers off. You'd basically get 7.1 Atmos.

You'd basically need a 7.1 DD+ non Atmos supporting AV receiver to be able to effectively test this. Even without the height speakers, a 7.1 configuration will result in you getting Atmos on an Atmos receiver.

#6

That depends on whether or not the audio is inclusive of Atmos or not. An Atmos setup will always priotioties the Atmos metadata which which then negate the channel based soundtrack. You'd basically have to disengage or turn off the height speakers in the setup to force the receiver to use the discrete channel based format the metadata was packaged with. Yes, the Atmos soundtrack uses the channel based audio, but Atmos AV receivers don't give you an option to flick between Atmos and the channel based audio, not without ammending the speaker configurations and disabling the height and or ceiling speakers.

It should also be noted that even without heoght speakers, an AV receiver will still give you Atmos if you've back surrounds present in a setup. This makes it practically impossible to actually portrat a discrete 7.1 soundtrack even if you turn the height speakers off. You'd basically get 7.1 Atmos.

Sure, there are plenty of people out there running a 7.1 speaker layout (no heights/wides etc) with an Atmos capable AVR. That's what I was referring to when I said "traditional non-Atmos 7.1 speaker layout". So yes it would be 7.1 Atmos, just streamed in a compressed form via a DD+ codec.

I'm interested because I find that, provided the sound mixer made good use of the extra channels, on Blu-ray discrete 7.1 HD soundtracks usually sound appreciably better than 5.1 ones upmixed to 7.1.

Until now I've always thought that my system's 7.1 speaker layout wouldn't benefit from moving to an Atmos capable AVR unless I added extra speakers but it looks like I'm wrong on that.

#7

Just tested this out with my Marantz SR7012. In the Amp Assign menu I set it to the default 9.1 with a 5CH & SB configuration and no heights. Speaker Config was set to 7.1.

TV is an LG E7 which can pass Atmos via ARC. Using the internal Apps Netflix, Disney+, Amazon and ATV+. Atmos tracks show as Atmos despite there being no height speakers (as @dante01 mentions above).

All 5.1 content comes up as 5.1 DD+ although you can then engage an upmixer if you want 7.1. What I can do though is force an Atmos track back to 5.1 DD+ by pressing the green Movie button on the remote.

Here's the weird bit. Both the Input and Output Channel Indicators think there's a 7.1 signal and the Surround Backs are active. They're not, they're silent*, as I have a poweramp for the five main channels that I can turn off so only the SB's are on.

Edit. Pressing the Status button to check the format also shows Dolby Digital+. Format 3/4/.1.

*Apart from ATV+ content

#8

I think it depends on what you have configured your amp as.

On my x1700 i can configure the 6th and 7th channels as

Front height, top front, top middle, front Dolby, surround Dolby. All of these support dolby Atmos and DTS:X

However if I specify they are surround back which I believe is the traditional 7.1 setup then neither dolby Atmos nor DTS:X are supported. I would assume then that any source device would be advised that these two formats aren't supported

#9

On most Atmos enabled AV receivers, if you've back surrounds sans any height speakers then the AV receiver will still detect Atmos or DTS:X metadata and portray the soundtrack as being onbect based. Height, ceiling or upward firing speakers are not a strict requirement for Atmos if you've back surrounds present in your setup.

Atmos can be portrayed via a 7.1 floor layer configuration. You'd obviously not experience the same overhead effects that you;d get if you had the heights or ceiling speakers though. The soundtrack being portrayed will be object based as opposed to channel based though and the AV receiver will be using the associated metadata.

What you cannot have is Atmos via a 5.1 setup absent of the back surrounds or height speakers, not without using Dolby Virtual Height processing.

There's no real advantage gained by portraying an Atmos soundtrack via a setup absent of height speakers.

There is if it will get you discrete 7.1 audio vs upmixed 5.1 audio over streaming services. The jump to discrete 7.1 when Blu-ray came along was IMO hugely significant. Those back speakers lit up like never before.

You didn't directly answer the question though. Do you actually know if you will get discrete 7.1 surround sound when streaming a 7.1.4 mixed Atmos track through a traditional 7.1 configured layout in an Atmos capable AVR?

I'm not actually expecting you to know because unless you've tried it yourself or know someone that has then you won't, you would just be speculating like me.

#13

Depends upon whether or not the soundtrack actually include 2 discrete back channels. If not then no, you'll never get discerete back channel audio.

I'd need access to the actual audio package to be able to ascertain this. This isn't something I'd be able to do if using one of the streaming services, not with the equipmemt or software I've got at my disposal.

There's usually metadata included with content that will state the exact audio configuration, including the number of discrete channels present in the channel based formatted audio as well as whether or not object based metadata is included.

The AV receiver would read the above mentioned metadata and give you the number of discrete channels present. I can only therefore assume that no, you are not getting discrete 7.1 DD+ if the AV receiver fails to report this?

You cannot create discrete channels, they have to be present in the audio to begin with.

#15

So on my x1700 I bet the following

Amp assign set to surround back

Netlflix plays Atmos film as Atmos and Denon app shows it's receiving Atmos DD+ 48kHz but doesn't show any discrete channels for input. Output is using SBR and SBL as configured in Amp assign.

Amp assign set to front height

Netlflix plays Atmos film as Atmos and Denon app shows it's receiving Atmos DD+ 48kHz but doesn't show any discrete channels for input. Output is using FHL and FHR as configured in Amp assign.

If i change the mode movie on the avr app from Atmos/DSurr to Dolby Audio - Dolby Digital Plus then I get the following

Amp assign set to surround back

Same film now netflix shows 5.1 Icon. Denon app shows it's receiving DD (no plus) 48kHz. Input now has discrete 5.1 Channels Output is 5.1 too.

Amp assign set to front height

Same film Netflix doesn't show audio format. Denon app shows it's receiving DD+ 48kHz. Input now has discrete 7.1 Channels. Output is also showing as 5.1 i.e. FHL and FHR are not lit up.

Not sure what to make of that using sound mode Dolby Audio - dolby Digital Plus, depending on the amp assign choice it seems Netflix changes between using DD and DD+

What does seem to be the case is with Atmos content no discrete input channels are shown by the avr app

#16

@Mr Wolf

Ok. Just re-installed the ATV+ App. Foundation comes up as Atmos but if I then force it back to DD+ it is indeed DD+ 7.1 as the SB's are still active. The signal format also shows 3/4/.1.

However, switching to DD+ 7.1 from Atmos appears to affect the content they produce. With Atmos they're more active with more effects such as music etc.

So, other ATV+ content is also showing as DD+ 7.1 albeit with less activity in the SB channels compared to Atmos decoding. Shining Girls, The Essex Serpent and Tehran are all in DD+ 7.1 but again with less SB activity.

As an aside for @dante01 and his comments above. He's correct. If the Surround Backs are configured then Atmos decoding is available. Turn them off in the Amp Assign menu and Atmos decoding is no longer an option. Only upmixing is available.

#22

Why would anyone want to encode a Blu-ray with DD+ and Atmos and why not simply use TrueHD as the channel based Atmos element? It isn't as though there's an issue with bandwidth if encoding a disc with a film.

#23

DD+ was a failure since it needed greater bandwidth (1.7 resp. 3MB/s) than S/PDIF (640KB/s), but the distribution formats (Bluray , UHD) all have the bandwidth (18MB/s) for True HD. With DD+ having lossy compression and True HD having lossless compression, it was a no-contest for physical formats.

DD+ only really had an opportunity with streaming services prepared to devote a higher bandwidth to audio than S/PDIF, but not enough that TrueHD was viable. Such sources are rare, most content providers preferring to offer more content channels than higher quality audio.

#24

DD+ was a failure since it needed greater bandwidth

I wouldn't call DD+ a failure at at all. In fact it's what most of us (AVR/AVP owners) are listening to from the current streaming services every day. It was just launched ahead of its time as Blu-ray came along shortly after it was released which removed the need for data compression in disc media.

My understanding is that it's been widely adopted by the streaming services as it's a far more bandwidth efficient codec than the old DD 5.1 (AC3). This allows them to allocate more bandwidth to the picture side of things.

DD+ actually has a variable bit rate (up to 6.144 Mb/s) and according to Anthony Grimani (ex-Dolby) at its higher rates offers a perceived quality on a par with the lossless formats. I'm hoping that in time, as broadband speeds increase, we'll see the streaming services adopt these higher bitrates so I can stop wanting to use disc media to get the best sound from my movies. I fear that may still be some way off though.

Last edited: May 19, 2022
